bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Colonel Ash, June 25, 1940

div1.p: Hench discusses the photographs of Camp Lazear and efforts to identify the site properly. He mentions interesting material at the University of Virginia. Hench plans to donate copies of his research material and photographs to the Army Medical Museum and to the University of Virginia. He seeks other photographs and a map of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Colonel Ash, June 25, 1940
div1.opener:
Y F
3/6/41 - sat
Me Port
June 25, 1940
Colonel Ash
Curator of the Army Medical Museum
Washington, D. C.
My dear Colonel Ash:
div1.p:
I am sorry that I did not got to see you again last week, to thank you
for your courtesy and the courtesy of Mr. Roy M. Reeve and of Major Davis. They
were very kind to me, and tremendously helpful. We uncovered some photographs
that will add materially to my proof as to the false location of the present
“Camp Lazear”. In particular, one old photograph of a model of Columbia Barracks
shows the location of the railroad tracks and the bridge over it, which is a
key factor in my documentary evidence. I was sorry not to be able to find any
photographs of Military Hospital No. 1, in Havana. This was located on Principe
Hill in Havana, and is where Agramonte had been assigned, and most of Agramonte's
work for the commission was done in this hospital. If you know of any place
where they might have photographs of this place, I shall be most happy to know
it.

Do you have any idea where Dr. Kelly got the photographs of Camp Lazear
which are in his book, WALTER REED AND YELLOW FEVER? I had assumed that they were
from your Medical Museum, but the photographs which you have are not like Dr.
Kelly's. Indeed, Kelly's are much clearer than yours.

I found some interesting material also in the Alderman Library at the
University of Virginia. Mr. Harry Clemons, librarian, very kindly put it at my
disposal. I am making a report on this for the Cuban government. I consider that
library and the Army Medical Museum as the two proper depositories for the material
I obtain, and I will see to it that you receive photographs and copies of my
documentary evidence.

I asked Major Davis if he knew of any possible source for an old map
of Camp Columbia and of Marianao. The official records, as given in Senate Document
822, indicate that one of the officers made a spot map of the epidemic of yellow fever
in Marianao, but Major Davis did not know where this might be obtained.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
